sub_title: Researcher (Corporate Accountability and Lobbying, Food and Beverage Industry)
summary:
Thorough, detail-oriented, and proactive, I am a researcher for the Access to Nutrition Initiative (ATNI), where I contribute to qualitative research, methodology development, report writing and stakeholder presentations across a range of topics and projects. My main topics of expertise food and beverage industry lobbying, stakeholder engagement, supply chain responsibility and governance. 

I am passionate about addressing sustainability in supply chains, market transformation and enhancing transparency/accountability mechanisms, especially in the food and clothing industries. 

I also have a strong interest and research experience in (shrinking) civic space for CSOs and citizens, and digital and policy approaches to addressing this issue.

profile_positions.description:
Global Index (and U.S. Index) - ATNI's flagship products:
- Responisble for researching the nutrition-related corporate practices of the world's largest food and beverage manufacturers
- Responsible for research quality assurance, analysis, and chapter writing for lobbying and stakeholder engagement 
- Contribute to methodology development and research process design
- Present findings and provide guidance to senior representatives of food and beverage companies and ATNI's signatory investors.

Researched and wrote exploratory report on emerging topic of address malnutrition among companies' supply chain workers across a range of sectors (agro-commodities and garments), including factory workers, farm estate workers, and smallholder farmers.

Conducted feasibility study of mechanisms to monitor and driver greater accountability for lobbying by Breastmilk-substitute (BMS) manufacturers:
- Researched existing lobbying transparency/accountability mechanisms in other sectors
- Interviewed cross-section of stakeholders in the infant nutrition/BMS space
- Wrote extensive report based on findings, presented to funder and key stakeholders

profile_positions.description:

University of Amsterdam | Apparel Supply Chain Research (December 2018 to February 2019)
